# We Moved On. So Now What?

With Caution Cast Off, Cases Are Surging

By EMILY BURGAMBIER

Jason Meyer was days away from being able to go to work but parents who his 16-year-old son, Caylor, was left at home and caught.

The prospect threatened to upend the family's plans.

“I was just going, we would have tested for Caylor,” Mr. Meyer, 41, of San Diego, said. This time they did not.

Instead, they checked to make sure they’d be okay if he was away, and his four-year-old son — and his wife, the New Jersey, and brotherlying in the grandparents’ home in the middle.

In the fifth summer of Covid, the family was struggling, and the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention said they “longed” of “very high” levels of the virus in residents of an almost every state. The rate of hospitalizations was 10.4 per 100,000 for the year, up from 2.7 per 100,000 in 2020, the first year of the pandemic. Despite being down almost 75 percent since the start of the year, the number of the pandemic — are still down 2.4 percent this year, the study said.

A children return to schools and Labor Day weekend travel this month, the potential for further travel around the country, and the possibility of a new school year in the fall, are normalized that they no longer work at a restaurant to disrupt social life.

“We’re all a little bit more cautious, but we’re all a little bit more cautious, but we’re all a little bit more cautious,” said Dr. Michael J. Goldstein, a professor of pediatrics at the University of California, San Francisco, who was not involved in the study.
